displayed_text: Patient: Yep. Doctor: Vitamin B-twelve once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You know. You have a drug, so it’s one pill each morning. Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on. Doctor: You still on the Zoloda? Today? Patient: Yes. Doctor: per day any other medicine vitamins? Patient: Yes. Doctor: multivitamin steady today? Patient: two more pills; Optim- and two more pills

Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It went a tiny bit down so. Patient: That’s good to hear. Doctor: Um hm. Absolutely. Patient: I was wondering, they said theys gon’ have cameras on. Doctor: Today? Healthcare Professional: Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right. Doctor: But given that you don’t have anything else visible and all these years you haven’t had anything evolve. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this is the only area, I am thinking it’s worthwhile considering the cryo procedure. Okay? Patient: The whole thing or is this a partial? Doctor: Well no I think almost all of the prostate will need to be cryoed. So that’s why I figure Dr. C____ should come in and talk to you. Explain the details of the procedure and he’s saying that urinary leakage and everything chances are about one in four after the procedure, but that’s the risk we take and remember we talked about that that you know do we want to take that leakage risk. But given what I’m seeing is it’s that or wait until the prostate gland blocks your urinary flow which is not a good outcome at all. Right, yeah. If that wasn’t such an immediate threat, then I would have said no just sit tight, don’t do anything. Patient: Right.

Patient: No. Doctor: but it’s just, you know, we obsess about numbers. So, we’re like, “GAHHHH, where’d the platelets go?” And, that’s that. Appetite loss… Family Member: Ohhhh… (laughter) Doctor: Can occur which we can only pray for. Doctor: I would say that’s about it. I mean, in terms of what I really see people feeling bad about. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the fatigue, you know, for somebody like you who is on the go constantly could be significant. Like, I don’t want to minimize that in the . You have Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The insurance part may take a little bit longer because, uh, I can’t, I don’t know enough about insurance to predict. It’s crazy. It’s silly. But that’s, you know. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But the drug’s like twelve thousand dollars a month. Family Member: Hum. You said one was going to be coming out on the market soon? Doctor: Oh. I’m sorry. I jumped, I jumped around. So, uh, I jumped to the radium thing. But there’s another trial that’s coming up. Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval.

Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot. Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot.

Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

Patient: Um, that’s it. Doctor: Uh, last time you talked to C_ about your fatigue at the end of the day. Patient: Eh, just tired at the end, at the end, after working all day. Doctor: Any pain anywhere? Patient: No. Doctor: Any belly pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have bleeding, bruising? Patient: No. Doctor: And any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. Bowels are moving

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and it would show probably very small areas. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and those are non-targetable. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s just the – the struggle is unless that thing whichever one decides to block anything off… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But everybody's on the second pill at the right dose, and the Xtandi. ‘ Patient: Okay, I think I understand that. Okay. Doctor: Yes. And if you try to look on the internet, it's not the way it is, they just literally opened this up. So when M____, who was one that was calling you, she just wanted to know if you are even interested. Because if so we would have to get a spot. And then when you come in, you see a W____ equivalent, but just somebody who knows that study better. Kind of like a M____ and a W____hybrid. And you would be seen across the hall in our other area, but you still have me you can't get rid of me. And then we just decide if this is the right thing or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The alternative would be you know, let's say you're not eligible or you're not interested, we would try a different study to see; we would get off that Xtandi and try something else. I just said, “Well you are already on the 80 maybe we can get this guy come back and do more.” So that's an option, but there are still more options. So I don't want you to worry if that one is not going to work or is not appealing. We got more options. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Oh good, good. Doctor: Alien DNA. Patient: My doctor watches the alien shows (laughs) Family Member: That’s everyone. Does that make you feel better. Patient: Okay great, man. I feel great now. I just, I just took the survey “Do I trust my doctor?” I gotta go back and change it. Doctor: Oh, my lord. Doctor: I find it interesting because they, not about the alien part, but they tell you a lot of cool stuff about weird places on earth that you didn’t know about. You’re like, oh, that’s kind of a cool place over there in, you know, Bulgaria or something. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, your next appointment is, uh, let’s see here. Patient: I have an appointment January twenty fifth for a hormone shot. Doctor: And to see me also? Patient: I don’t have anything, uh, with you yet. Family Member: Are you sure?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So if you have one of those gasping things, if it’s your old gasping problem or is it the new drug? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So then we’re going to put you on steroids and stuff like that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It can attack your colon so then you can have just profuse, non-stop diarrhea and so that we have to stop as well. It can attack your liver so then you get a hepatitis- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. Tiredness was my biggest obstacle. Doctor: Tired is definitely. Family Member: Fatigue was unbelievable. So have you decided? Patient: Too early to decide. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: Yeah, so we need more information about the chest scan. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I want to give you some stuff that you can sort of read to educate yourself a bit more on options. And again you can lay it off to Dr. G as to his thoughts as to what the next steps would be in terms of scans or such. So other questions while I do a little bit more of this paperwork stuff? (keyboarding) Family Member: No, I don’t think so. Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___?
